# Cousin Languages
[Cousin-language](Cousin-language.html)s constitue a new framework to capture insights of modern flow theories, regional grammatical and lexical features.


Different kinds of relatedness, all denoted by ' > ' in here:  
  * direct inheritance (old german ⇨ german)  
  * direct inheritance within the same family (gothic⇨german)  
  * shift inheritance within the same family (gothic⇨german)  
  * shift inheritance within the superfamily (latin⇨english) “recognized loans”  
  * folk etymology and synesthesic *influence**  
  * re-connections : words with divergent sound and meaning are correctly recognized to be related and reassimilated  
  * unrecognized loans within the superfamily (modern english⇨hindi)  
  * calque clusters  
  * loan clusters  
  * loans with [phono-semantic-matching](phono-semantic-matching.html)  
  * loans with partial [calque](calque.html)s  
  * [wanderwort](wanderwort.html)s widespread loans  
  * shifting phonetics down the universal [sound-change](sound-change.html) gradient ( pot > pod boot > bod > fud > Fuß )  

As the Sumerian and Egyptian early dynasties share [common](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egypt%E2%80%93Mesopotamia_relations) [origins](susa-egypt.png)  , the writing system initially looked rather similar:  
![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a9/Tableta_con_trillo.png)  
Kish tablet 3500 BC
